title: 2 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who began to reign in Samaria over Israel in the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah?
options: Hoshea son of Elah
Jeroboam son of Nebat
Shalmaneser king of Assyria
So king of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Hoshea son of Elah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:1 states that Hoshea the son of Elah began to reign in Samaria over Israel in the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah.

questions.question: How long did Hoshea reign over Israel?
options: Nine years
Twelve years
Three years
Seven years
questions.correctAnswer: Nine years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:1 states that Hoshea reigned over Israel for nine years.

questions.question: What did Hoshea do in the sight of the LORD?
options: Did evil, but not as the kings before him
Did good and followed the LORD
Did nothing notable
Rebuilt the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Did evil, but not as the kings before him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:2 mentions that Hoshea did that which was evil in the sight of the LORD, but not as the kings of Israel that were before him.

questions.question: Who came up against Hoshea and made him his servant?
options: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
So king of Egypt
Jeroboam son of Nebat
Ahaz king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Shalmaneser king of Assyria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:3 states that Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Hoshea, and Hoshea became his servant.

questions.question: Why did the king of Assyria imprison Hoshea?
options: Hoshea conspired with the king of Egypt and did not pay tribute
Hoshea rebelled openly
Hoshea fled the land
Hoshea destroyed the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Hoshea conspired with the king of Egypt and did not pay tribute
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:4 explains that the king of Assyria found conspiracy in Hoshea because he sent messengers to the king of Egypt and did not bring tribute to Assyria as before, so he was imprisoned.

questions.question: For how many years did the king of Assyria besiege Samaria?
options: Three years
One year
Nine years
Seven years
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:5 says the king of Assyria besieged Samaria three years.

questions.question: Where did the king of Assyria carry Israel after taking Samaria?
options: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and cities of the Medes
Egypt
Babylon
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and cities of the Medes
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:6 states that Israel was carried away into Assyria and placed in Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and the cities of the Medes.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Israel walked in the statutes of the heathen and built high places in all their cities.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:8-9 describe how the children of Israel walked in the statutes of the heathen and built high places in all their cities.

questions.question: What did the children of Israel do that provoked the LORD to anger?
options: Burned incense in all the high places like the heathen
Followed the LORD faithfully
Built only one temple
Refused to build altars
questions.correctAnswer: Burned incense in all the high places like the heathen
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:11 says they burnt incense in all the high places as did the heathen, provoking the LORD to anger.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD sent lions among the nations placed in Samaria because they did not fear the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:25 explains that lions were sent among the nations in Samaria because they feared not the LORD.

questions.question: What did the king of Assyria command to be done to teach the nations about the God of the land?
options: Carry one of the priests from Israel to dwell there and teach them
Destroy all idols
Send the nations back to their own lands
Build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Carry one of the priests from Israel to dwell there and teach them
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:27 states the king of Assyria commanded to carry one of the priests to teach the nations the manner of the God of the land.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'But the LORD, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt with great power and a stretched out arm, him shall ye ______.'
options: fear
ignore
disobey
worship false gods
questions.correctAnswer: fear
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:36 says the LORD who brought them out of Egypt shall be feared, highlighting the command to fear Him alone.

questions.question: What did the children of Israel do that caused the LORD to remove them out of his sight?
options: Sinned against the LORD and served other gods
Built the temple
Obeyed the commandments
Made peace with Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Sinned against the LORD and served other gods
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:7-8 explains that Israel sinned and feared other gods, which caused the LORD to remove them.

questions.question: True or False: Judah was completely faithful and kept all the commandments of the LORD their God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:19 reveals that Judah also did not keep the commandments of the LORD but walked in their own statutes.

questions.question: Which king drove Israel from following the LORD and made them sin a great sin?
options: Jeroboam son of Nebat
Hoshea son of Elah
Ahaz king of Judah
Shalmaneser king of Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:21 states that Jeroboam son of Nebat made Israel sin a great sin by driving them from following the LORD.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to follow worldly ways rather than God’s commands. Based on 2 Kings 17, what biblical truth would you share about obedience?
options: Obedience to God's commandments is essential to avoid the consequences of sin.
Following the customs of surrounding nations is acceptable if it brings peace.
Ignoring the prophets is wise because they only bring condemnation.
Worshiping many gods shows spiritual growth and understanding.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's commandments is essential to avoid the consequences of sin.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:7-13 explains Israel's sin and disobedience by following other gods and ignoring God's commandments, resulting in their exile. This shows the importance of obedience to God's Word.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 17 teach us about humility when facing discipline and trials?
options: We should humbly accept God's correction and turn back to Him.
We can resist God's discipline and still expect His blessings.
Pride in our own ways leads to God's favor.
Ignoring God's warnings shows strength in trials.
questions.correctAnswer: We should humbly accept God's correction and turn back to Him.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 show that God sent prophets to call Israel to repentance. Their refusal led to exile, emphasizing the need for humility and repentance in trials.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about the consequences of sin in their family. Based on 2 Kings 17, what encouragement about God's justice and mercy would you offer?
options: God disciplines sin but remains faithful to His covenant and offers ways to return.
Once punished, God never restores those who sin.
God only cares about individual sin, not family or community.
Punishment is permanent without hope of mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines sin but remains faithful to His covenant and offers ways to return.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:18-20 describes God's judgment but also highlights His covenant relationship and calls to obedience in later verses (35-39), showing His ongoing faithfulness and mercy.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 17 illustrate the importance of spiritual leadership and teaching within a community?
options: The king of Assyria sent a priest to teach the new inhabitants how to fear God.
Leaders should focus only on political power, not spiritual guidance.
Spiritual teaching is unnecessary if people have different gods.
Only prophets can lead a community in faith.
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Assyria sent a priest to teach the new inhabitants how to fear God.
questions.explanation: Verses 26-28 show the Assyrian king commanding a priest to teach the people the ways of the God of the land, emphasizing the need for spiritual instruction.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 17 teach us about the dangers of syncretism or mixing worship of the true God with other gods?
options: Mixing true worship with idolatry leads to spiritual compromise and God's anger.
It is acceptable to worship multiple gods as a way to respect all cultures.
Idolatry is harmless if you also fear the LORD.
God blesses those who adopt the gods of neighboring nations.
questions.correctAnswer: Mixing true worship with idolatry leads to spiritual compromise and God's anger.
questions.explanation: Verses 29-41 describe how the nations feared the LORD but also served their own gods, which provoked God's anger and resulted in judgment.

questions.question: A believer asks about the role of covenant faithfulness in living a godly life. What does 2 Kings 17 reveal about this?
options: Faithfulness to God’s covenant is essential and rejecting it leads to ruin.
Covenants with God are optional and can be ignored without consequence.
The covenant was only for Israel and has no relevance today.
God changes His covenant based on people's choices.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God’s covenant is essential and rejecting it leads to ruin.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 and 35-39 emphasize Israel’s rejection of God’s covenant and the resulting consequences, underscoring the importance of covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 17 encourage perseverance through trials and exile?
options: Fearing the LORD and remaining faithful leads to eventual deliverance from enemies.
Trials mean God has abandoned you permanently.
Exile is a sign to stop trusting God.
God’s protection depends on human strength, not obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: Fearing the LORD and remaining faithful leads to eventual deliverance from enemies.
questions.explanation: Verse 39 promises that fearing the LORD leads to deliverance from enemies, encouraging perseverance and trust during hardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 17, the children of Israel completely obeyed God's commandments until their exile.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:7-23 details Israel’s persistent sinning, idolatry, and rejection of God's commandments leading to their exile.

questions.question: True or False: The nations placed by the Assyrians in Samaria immediately feared and obeyed the LORD fully according to His laws.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 29-41 show that these nations feared the LORD but also served their own gods and did not follow God's laws, continuing in old sinful ways.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Kings 17, the LORD commanded, "Ye shall not fear other gods, nor bow yourselves to them, nor serve them, nor _______ to them."
options: sacrifice
pray
listen
build temples
questions.correctAnswer: sacrifice
questions.explanation: Verse 35 specifically commands not to sacrifice to other gods, emphasizing exclusive worship of the LORD.

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 17, how should believers respond when they see others worshiping idols alongside the true God?
options: Remain faithful to God alone and avoid syncretism.
Join in to maintain social peace.
Ignore the issue as it does not affect personal faith.
Accept all forms of worship as equally valid.
questions.correctAnswer: Remain faithful to God alone and avoid syncretism.
questions.explanation: Verses 12 and 33 warn against serving idols and mixing worship, urging exclusive devotion to the LORD.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 17 teach about the consequences of rejecting God's statutes and covenant for family and community life?
options: Rejecting God's laws leads to spiritual decay and eventual exile.
Rejection of God's statutes strengthens family bonds.
Ignoring God's covenant brings material prosperity.
Covenant rejection has no real impact on communities.
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God's laws leads to spiritual decay and eventual exile.
questions.explanation: Verses 14-20 describe how Israel's rejection of God's statutes led to their downfall and exile, affecting the entire nation.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 17 emphasize the importance of teaching future generations about God’s laws and covenant?
options: Neglecting to teach leads to continued sin and disobedience across generations.
Only adults need to learn about God's laws.
Children naturally follow God without instruction.
Teaching God's laws is optional for spiritual growth.
questions.correctAnswer: Neglecting to teach leads to continued sin and disobedience across generations.
questions.explanation: Verse 41 highlights how children and grandchildren continued in sin like their fathers, showing the need for faithful teaching.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 17, what practical step did the king of Assyria take to address the spiritual ignorance of the new inhabitants in Samaria?
options: He brought a priest from Israel to teach them how to fear the LORD.
He forced them to abandon all their gods immediately.
He ignored their spiritual condition.
He built new temples for their gods.
questions.correctAnswer: He brought a priest from Israel to teach them how to fear the LORD.
questions.explanation: Verses 26-28 describe the Assyrian king sending an Israelite priest to instruct the new settlers in the fear of God.

questions.question: How can 2 Kings 17 guide a believer’s work ethic and integrity in daily life?
options: Faithfulness to God's commandments includes honesty and integrity in all actions.
Work ethic is unrelated to spiritual obedience.
Success justifies dishonest means if necessary.
Integrity is secondary to cultural customs.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God's commandments includes honesty and integrity in all actions.
questions.explanation: The chapter’s emphasis on obedience to God’s statutes (verses 12-13, 35-37) implies that faithfulness covers all life areas including integrity and honesty.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who was the king of Israel when Hoshea began to reign, and in which year of his reign did Hoshea start ruling?
options: Ahaz, twelfth year
Hezekiah, third year
Jeroboam II, ninth year
Rehoboam, fifth year
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaz, twelfth year
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:1 states that Hoshea began to reign in the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah.

questions.question: What was the nature of Hoshea's actions according to the LORD's perspective, and how did it compare to previous kings of Israel?
options: He did evil, but not as previous kings
He was righteous unlike previous kings
He was neutral, neither evil nor good
He fully obeyed the LORD like David
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil, but not as previous kings
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:2 indicates that Hoshea did evil in the sight of the LORD, but not as the kings of Israel before him.

questions.question: Which Assyrian king besieged Samaria and eventually took it, leading to the exile of Israel?
options: Shalmaneser
Sargon
Tiglath-Pileser
Esarhaddon
questions.correctAnswer: Shalmaneser
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:3-6 describe Shalmaneser king of Assyria coming up against Hoshea, besieging Samaria for three years, taking it, and carrying Israel into exile.

questions.question: What was the reason for the Assyrian king imprisoning Hoshea?
options: Hoshea conspired with Egypt and withheld tribute
Hoshea rebelled openly with an army
Hoshea refused to worship Assyrian gods
Hoshea fled to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Hoshea conspired with Egypt and withheld tribute
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:4 explains that Shalmaneser found conspiracy in Hoshea because he sent messengers to the king of Egypt and did not bring a present to Assyria as before, so he was bound in prison.

questions.question: Where did the Assyrians relocate the people of Israel after conquering Samaria?
options: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and cities of the Medes
Babylon and Ur
Jerusalem and Bethel
Nineveh and Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and cities of the Medes
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:6 states that Israel was taken to Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and the cities of the Medes.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The children of Israel sinned against the LORD by doing what, which provoked Him to anger?
options: Fearing other gods and walking in statutes of heathen
Building the temple in Jerusalem
Offering sacrifices only to the LORD
Keeping the Sabbath strictly
questions.correctAnswer: Fearing other gods and walking in statutes of heathen
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:7-8 explains Israel's sin was fearing other gods and walking in statutes of heathen nations.

questions.question: What specific idolatrous practices did Israel engage in according to 2 Kings 17?
options: Building high places, setting up images and groves, burning incense
Only worshiping Baal in secret
Making pilgrimages to Jerusalem
Constructing altars only for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Building high places, setting up images and groves, burning incense
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 describe secret evil deeds, building high places, setting up images and groves, and burning incense provoking the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Despite the LORD's prophets urging Israel and Judah to repent, they hardened their necks and refused to obey.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:13-14 state that the LORD testified through prophets but they hardened their necks like their fathers and did not believe.

questions.question: How did the Israelites violate the covenant made with their ancestors according to this chapter?
options: By rejecting statutes, following vanity, and worshiping other gods
By building the temple in Jerusalem
By observing only the Sabbath
By keeping all commandments perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: By rejecting statutes, following vanity, and worshiping other gods
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:15 explains Israel rejected the covenant, followed vanity, and went after surrounding heathen gods contrary to the LORD's command.

questions.question: Which gods or idols did Israel worship, as mentioned in this chapter, that provoked the LORD to anger?
options: Two calves, groves, host of heaven, and Baal
Only the LORD God of Israel
The Egyptian gods of Pharaoh
The Canaanite moon god only
questions.correctAnswer: Two calves, groves, host of heaven, and Baal
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:16 mentions Israel made molten images of two calves, groves, worshipped heavenly hosts, and served Baal.

questions.question: What dreadful acts did Israel perform involving their children that further provoked the LORD?
options: Causing sons and daughters to pass through fire, divination, enchantments
Offering them as sacrifices only to the LORD
Sending them to study abroad
Raising them strictly in the Law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Causing sons and daughters to pass through fire, divination, enchantments
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:17 states Israel caused children to pass through fire, practiced divination and enchantments, provoking the LORD.

questions.question: What was the LORD's response to Israel's sins, leading to their removal from His sight?
options: He was very angry and removed them, leaving only Judah
He blessed them abundantly
He ignored their sins
He gave them double portion of land
questions.correctAnswer: He was very angry and removed them, leaving only Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:18 explains that the LORD's anger caused Israel to be removed, with only Judah remaining.

questions.question: Which king did the LORD raise up after He rent Israel from the house of David, who led Israel into great sin?
options: Jeroboam son of Nebat
Rehoboam son of Solomon
Hezekiah son of Ahaz
Ahab son of Omri
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:21 states Jeroboam son of Nebat was made king and caused Israel to sin greatly.

questions.question: What strategy did the king of Assyria use to try to stabilize the people he placed in Samaria after deporting Israel?
options: He brought a priest from Israel to teach the manner of the God of the land
He forced them to worship idols only
He left them without religious guidance
He sent prophets to curse them
questions.correctAnswer: He brought a priest from Israel to teach the manner of the God of the land
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:26-27 shows the Assyrian king commanded that an Israelite priest be brought to teach the new inhabitants how to fear the LORD.

questions.question: Despite fearing the LORD, how did the nations placed in Samaria behave religiously according to verse 33?
options: They served their own gods as well, mixing worship practices
They abandoned all gods and worshipped only the LORD
They fasted and prayed continuously
They returned to Israelite customs fully
questions.correctAnswer: They served their own gods as well, mixing worship practices
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:33 states that these nations feared the LORD but also served their own gods after the manner of their former nations.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 17, what was the primary reason for the exile of Israel by the king of Assyria?
options: They sinned against the LORD by worshiping other gods and breaking His covenant.
They refused to pay tribute to the king of Assyria.
They allied with Egypt against Assyria.
They rebelled militarily against Assyria.
questions.correctAnswer: They sinned against the LORD by worshiping other gods and breaking His covenant.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:7-8 explains that Israel sinned against the LORD by fearing other gods and following statutes of the heathen. This unfaithfulness led to their exile. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 28:15-68 which outlines curses for covenant disobedience, Jeremiah 25:8-11 which prophesied exile for Israel’s sin, Ezekiel 20:13-21 that describes idolatry as cause for judgment, and Romans 1:18-32 which teaches God's wrath against sin.

questions.question: Who was the king of Israel when Hoshea began to reign, as mentioned in 2 Kings 17?
options: Hoshea was king over Israel; Ahaz was king over Judah.
Ahaz was king over Israel; Hoshea was king over Judah.
Jeroboam was king over Israel.
Hezekiah was king over Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: Hoshea was king over Israel; Ahaz was king over Judah.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:1 states that Hoshea began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah. This shows the contemporaneous reigns of the northern and southern kingdoms. This aligns with the division of Israel and Judah after Solomon's reign (1 Kings 12:20), and the parallel accounts of kings in 2 Chronicles.

questions.question: What was the consequence of Hoshea's conspiracy against the king of Assyria?
options: Hoshea was imprisoned by the king of Assyria.
Hoshea was killed in battle.
Hoshea fled to Egypt.
Hoshea was forgiven and restored.
questions.correctAnswer: Hoshea was imprisoned by the king of Assyria.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:4 reports that the king of Assyria found conspiracy in Hoshea because he sent messengers to the king of Egypt and failed to pay tribute. As a result, Hoshea was shut up and bound in prison. This judgment corresponds with God's warnings about unfaithfulness and political rebellion (Isaiah 8:7-8, Jeremiah 27:12-15).

questions.question: How long did the king of Assyria besiege Samaria before capturing it?
options: Three years
One year
Six months
Ten years
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:5 states that the king of Assyria besieged Samaria for three years before taking it in the ninth year of Hoshea (verse 6). This prolonged siege emphasizes the certainty of God's judgment on Israel for sin, paralleling other biblical sieges such as the siege of Jerusalem (Jeremiah 52:5-6).

questions.question: Where were the Israelites relocated following their exile by Assyria?
options: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and the cities of the Medes
Babylon and Nineveh
Egypt and Philistia
Jerusalem and Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Halah, Habor by the river of Gozan, and the cities of the Medes
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:6 records that the king of Assyria carried Israel away and placed them in Halah, in Habor by the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes. This scattering fulfills the covenant curses in Deuteronomy 28:64 and corresponds to the theme of exile as a consequence of covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What sin did Israel commit that is specifically mentioned as provoking the LORD to anger in 2 Kings 17?
options: Burning incense in high places and serving idols
Refusing to build the temple
Neglecting the Sabbath
Denying the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Burning incense in high places and serving idols
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:11-12 highlights that Israel burnt incense in all the high places and served idols, sins that provoked the LORD to anger. This idolatry violates the first and second commandments (Exodus 20:3-5), and is condemned throughout Scripture (Psalm 115:4-8, Isaiah 44:9-20).

questions.question: Despite prophetic warnings, how did Israel respond to the calls for repentance?
options: They hardened their necks and refused to listen.
They repented and returned to the LORD.
They ignored the prophets and worshiped only Yahweh.
They sought alliances with neighboring nations.
questions.correctAnswer: They hardened their necks and refused to listen.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:13-14 states that the LORD testified against Israel by prophets, but they did not listen and hardened their necks like their fathers who did not believe in the LORD. This reflects the biblical theme of human stubbornness against divine revelation (Jeremiah 7:25-26, Romans 1:18-32).

questions.question: Which of the following practices did Israel adopt that demonstrated their departure from the LORD's commandments?
options: Making molten images, worshipping Baal, and passing children through fire
Building the temple in Jerusalem
Observing the Passover according to the law
Offering sacrifices only at the tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Making molten images, worshipping Baal, and passing children through fire
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:16-17 records that Israel made molten images, worshipped Baal, and passed their children through fire, all forbidden practices provoking God's wrath (Leviticus 18:21, Deuteronomy 12:29-31). This idolatry contrasts with true worship and leads to judgment (Jeremiah 19:5).

questions.question: What was God's response to Israel's persistent sin and idolatry as described in this chapter?
options: He was very angry and removed them from His sight, leaving only Judah.
He forgave them despite their sins.
He sent an angel to destroy only the wicked.
He strengthened their kingdom.
questions.correctAnswer: He was very angry and removed them from His sight, leaving only Judah.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:18 declares that the LORD was very angry and removed Israel out of His sight, leaving only the tribe of Judah. This judicial removal is a fulfillment of covenant curses (Leviticus 26:33, Jeremiah 30:11) and demonstrates God's holiness and justice.

questions.question: After Israel's exile, what did the king of Assyria do with other nations, and what was the initial result?
options: He brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Ava, Hamath, and Sepharvaim to dwell in Samaria, but lions killed some of them.
He left the cities empty and abandoned.
He returned the land to Judah.
He made Samaria a vassal state without inhabitants.
questions.correctAnswer: He brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Ava, Hamath, and Sepharvaim to dwell in Samaria, but lions killed some of them.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:24-25 explains that the king of Assyria settled various nations in Samaria, but they feared not the LORD and lions killed some of them. This shows the spiritual consequences of ignoring the true God (Psalm 91:13, Proverbs 28:1).

questions.question: How did the king of Assyria attempt to resolve the problem of lions killing those settled in Samaria?
options: He commanded to bring a priest from Israel to teach the people the manner of the God of the land.
He ordered the city walls to be rebuilt.
He sent a military force to kill the lions.
He relocated the people to another land.
questions.correctAnswer: He commanded to bring a priest from Israel to teach the people the manner of the God of the land.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:26-27 records the king of Assyria’s command to bring an Israelite priest to instruct the new inhabitants in the worship of the LORD. This reflects God's desire for proper worship and instruction (Deuteronomy 31:9-13, Nehemiah 8:1-8).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 17 teach about the nations settled in Samaria concerning their worship practices?
options: They feared the LORD but also served their own gods according to their former customs.
They fully abandoned idolatry and worshiped only the LORD.
They rejected all forms of worship.
They adopted the worship of Israel exclusively.
questions.correctAnswer: They feared the LORD but also served their own gods according to their former customs.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:33 shows that these nations feared the LORD, yet they served their own gods in the way they were accustomed, mixing worship practices. This syncretism is condemned throughout Scripture (Exodus 34:14, 2 Corinthians 6:14-18).

questions.question: What covenant stipulations concerning worship does the chapter emphasize that Israel failed to uphold?
options: They were commanded not to fear or serve other gods but only the LORD, who brought them out of Egypt.
They were commanded to worship idols alongside the LORD.
They were told to build altars for all gods.
They were instructed to have multiple priests for different gods.
questions.correctAnswer: They were commanded not to fear or serve other gods but only the LORD, who brought them out of Egypt.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:35-36 emphasizes the covenant command not to fear or serve other gods, but only the LORD who delivered Israel from Egypt. This is consistent with the Shema (Deuteronomy 6:4-5), Exodus 20:3-5, and Jesus’ teaching on the greatest commandment (Mark 12:29-30).

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 17 describe Israel’s attitude toward God's statutes and covenant by the end of the chapter?
options: They did not heed the covenant and continued in their former manner of sin.
They renewed their covenant and followed God's laws faithfully.
They were indifferent and ignored all religion.
They only worshiped God during festivals.
questions.correctAnswer: They did not heed the covenant and continued in their former manner of sin.
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 17:40-41 states that the people did not listen but continued their former ways, fearing the LORD and serving graven images simultaneously. This persistent rebellion illustrates the hardness of human hearts (Romans 2:5, Hebrews 3:8).

questions.question: What theological truth about God is underscored by His removal of Israel due to their idolatry and covenant breach?
options: God is holy and just, punishing sin but also faithful to His covenant promises.
God is indifferent to human sin.
God only punishes nations, not individuals.
God abandons His people permanently without hope.
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and just, punishing sin but also faithful to His covenant promises.
questions.explanation: The chapter demonstrates God's holiness and justice in punishing Israel’s sin (2 Kings 17:18,20), yet His faithfulness to the covenant and promises about restoration are evident in Scripture (Jeremiah 31:31-34, Ezekiel 36:24-28, Romans 11:26).
